transcription.full_transcript: In October 2016, I was invited by the Google Cultural Institute to join a summit on machine learning that was being convened in Paris the following month. At that time, Google had just released Deep Dream, a program that uses neural networks to produce surreal psychedelic images by amplifying patterns within existing images. Upon its release, artists across the world were quickly captivated by what appeared to be a new form of vision being produced by artificial intelligence. And it was on this basis that the summit was organised to explore potential projects at the intersection of art and machine learning. Arriving in Paris on a chilly morning with a few hours to spare before the summit, I thought I should visit a museum. Having recently read about the Mus√©e de Calbonne-Lys, a museum of world cultures located along the Seine River, I decided to go and check out his collection, which, as I had learned, partly originates from the colonial conquests of the French Empire. At the museum, as I walked through the vast collection of artefacts from every region in the world, I found myself contemplating not only the objects, but also their modes of display, which often featured captions that reminded viewers of the problematic conditions under which these objects were first amassed. and exhibited. At that time, it was still two years before the publishing of a landmark report that recommended the restitution of objects taken from Africa during the colonial period. Yet, in these anxious annotations, one could already sense the beginning of the unraveling of the prevailing global imperial order as it reckoned with the ghosts of its past. Moreover, as I was reflecting on what it meant to represent these objects today as witnesses of colonial history. I was reminded of the profound temporal paradox upon which the colonial museum was constructed to begin with. On the one hand, as a museum, the colonial museum was responsible for the collection and preservation of objects whose value derived from their authenticity as established through tracing their histories. However, as an ideological apparatus that produced knowledge about the colonies, the Colonial Museum was also tasked with reducing the complicated histories of these objects to a singular narrative that a colonial project sought to tell about itself. Often, this process required nothing less than the concealment of the objects'very historicity. Of the fact that they were produced, used, and eventually plundered, at a particular place and time. This was done not simply to conceal the more unsavoury aspects of colonial rule, but also so that the colonial museum could present these objects not as the products of history, but of couches imagined to be naturally inferior, and whose colonial subjugation is accordingly not a historical contingency, but something necessary to human progress. And so it was in the midst of my musings on the ahistorical time of the Colonial Museum that I left the Calbronley and headed for the Arts and Machine Learning Summit at the Google Cultural Institute, where, quite unexpectedly, I found myself once again contemplating the question of history. At the summit, I listened to a talk by the French artist and interaction designer Cyril Diani, who presented his application called Portrait Matcher. Developed during his residency at the Google Arts and Culture Lab, the application allows users to upload any photograph with a human face, which is then analysed through machine learning to be matched with a face appearing within the 40,000 digital reproductions of artworks in Google's collection. As he was showing us an example of the matches derived by the application, I noticed a familiar face, which, as I could tell almost immediately, belongs to this well-known painting. permanently displayed at the National Gallery Singapore. Epic poem of Malaya. completed by the social realist painter Chua Mya Thi in 1955. So excited was I to see this Singaporean art historical icon make an unexpected appearance that I was able to look past the lack of resemblance between the two faces matched by the application. However, revisiting this moment today, I have some questions. For one, what does it mean for this image? to be extracted from a national collection so as to enter an artificial neural network where it becomes a part of another work of art. What happens to the value of the image as determined by its place within a national narrative when a copy of it leaves the custodianship of the state and cycles through a neural network in search of another version of itself? And how can the journey of this image speak to the ongoing shift from images created through direct observation of the world, to images generated by artificial intelligence from archives of pre-existing images. What becomes of representation when such images are then presented as original, despite being constituted from the traces of images originating from different archives, from different histories? If our detour to the Colonial Museum has taught us anything, It is that the obliteration of history has itself a history. Figures of History. The year is 1955. The young painter, Chua Mya Tee, has completed what will later become one of his best-known works, Epic Poem of Malaya. In the British colonial port city of Singapore, where he grew up and lives, The new constitution grants many of the city's mostly immigrant population the right to vote for the first time. While falling short of full self-governance, the move marks the first tentative step taken by the people of the city towards post-colonial nationhood. But more than a security operation, this experiment in pastoralising a population that had been mostly living within squatter settlements was initially also conceived as part of a campaign to win their hearts and minds. The idea was that by allowing them to enjoy the material comforts such as education and healthcare, which came with living within the planned community, the villagers would be convinced of the merits of social democracy over communism. However, the British strategy quickly unravelled as the villagers grew to resent their containment and surveillance over time, with some even throwing their lot with the communists. In the 2014 science fiction film, Edge of Tomorrow, the plot revolves around a US military officer, William Cage, played by Tom Cruise, who finds himself in a time loop after being killed in a battle against an alien race known as the Mimics. With each repetition of the loop, Cage becomes more competent on the battlefield, eventually catching the attention of Rita Wartowski, an exceptionally skilled combatant played by Emily Blunt, who is aware of the time loop phenomenon. Wartowski explains to Cage that he gained the ability to reset the day after absorbing the blood of a rare type of mimic known as the alpha, which is able to trigger a restart of the day each time it is killed. Having once been exposed to the blood of an alpha, and gain the same ability to repeat the day. only to lose it after a blood transfusion. Fratowski convinces Cage that his ability to get better at defeating the Mimics with each loop is the only way they can win the war, and teams up with him for this mission to save humanity. Age of Tomorrow is one of numerous films made within the past decade or so that deployed the plot device of the time loop that was first popularized by the 1993 film Groundhog Day. While earlier films within the genre mostly used the device to explore questions of a more existential register. In the recent wave of time loop films, the loop more often serves as a tool for defeating a powerful and malicious entity, whether it be an alien race, a corrupt politician in control of the state's security apparatus, or a tech monopoly that has taken over the state. Across these films, a recurring motive is the contrast between the protagonist's consciousness of the loop and the ignorance of the other characters whose actions and words are easily anticipated by the protagonist. This sets up a narrative that pits the characters who appear to be just repeating a predetermined plan against the hero who is able to exploit the loop to explore the different ways the events of the day can unfold. Unlike in the conventional time travel story, where the protagonist embarks on a high-stakes mission to alter the course of history in a manner that is often irreversible, Time here has been transformed into a resource so unlimited that it is treated as literally disposable, with the hero often choosing to die and reset the day whenever the slightest mistake is made. But as important as the affordances of time are those of space, for with each iteration of the loop, the protagonist improves his chances of survival by seeking out the best possible way of navigating the space in which he finds himself. That space here is more often than not urban space, further allows the protagonist to leverage a vast network of logistical and communicative channels in his quest to master the map and escape the loop once and for all. Given that in many of these films, the premise involves a nefarious plot to take over a community or even the entire human race, all these elements come together to render the narrative as a contest between the plan and the feedback loop. between the singular force of an all-too-powerful entity modeled after the state, and the seemingly unlimited capacity for making connections within a network. So confounded was I by this phenomenon that I started to suspect that my programmer had slipped in a photo of his grandfather into the training data, perhaps as a bad joke. It seems then that in my inability to comprehend the seemingly disembodied intelligence that could have conjured such an image, I intuitively turned towards the body of my programmer, uploading and labelling the data. At the very least, I was confident that he is a human being. and not a robot. So returning to the question of bias, I figured based on my experience that perhaps locating the problem in the dataset rather than the neural network allows us to attribute it to some form of human intention, thus deferring the question of what exactly happens when an image enters a neural network. After all, a world controlled by racist programmers makes for a much less unsettling thought. than a world ruled by racist machines with no human body behind them, not least machines that seem to lack any kind of physical form altogether. Yet, as any student of technological history would know, the questions being raised now around the relationship between technology and embodiment did not originate with generative AI. For one, the ARPANET, the precursor to the internet that was developed in the 1960s, under the US Department of Defense, was explicitly inspired by early cybernetic research into the brain. Taking reference from how neurons in the brain form connections with other neurons to transmit information, the ARPANET was designed as a distributed network where computers can communicate directly with each other through interconnected nodes without going through a center. In the context of the ever imminent threat of a nuclear attack, the strength of such a network was that it allowed information to flow even if certain nodes were taken offline, similar to how the brain adapts and reroutes signals when certain areas are damaged. However, where this biological metaphor took a strange, almost metaphysical turn, was when the network grew to a point where it could no longer be encompassed by the state. By the late 1980s, the ARPANET had evolved into the Internet through the interconnection of multiple networks and was being used across government organizations. and academic institutions. Against the backdrop of a bubbling ideological cocktail of techno-utopianism and market fundamentalism centered on the California Bay Area, The publicly funded open protocol architecture of the internet was subsequently deregulated in the 1990s, transforming the network into a truly public good and opening it up for commercial exploitation at the same time. As we now know, what followed was the proliferation of a whole host of applications, including the World Wide Web, and in time, the emergence of a new economy of free and data-rich platforms built on casualised and poorly remunerated labour. In this double movement of the nation entering the network, just as the network enters the market, what changed was not just the scale of the network, but also the very concept of the network as a brain for a larger body politic. As the media historian Benjamin Peters suggests, when neoliberal proponents of the internet imagine the transformation of the nation into a network, what they see is not so much that the body of the nation, gains a brain in the form of the network, then that it becomes one in its entirety, with the bodies that make up the nation in turn becoming neurons within the network. In other words, the brain here is not a tentacular omega sitting at the center of a vast network, but an entirely disembodied network of neurons firing at each other without taking direction from a center. A brain without a body. This disappearance of the body politic effectively transforms the nation into a kind of marketplace of individuals, imagined less as bodies engaged in physical labour, than as purely cognitive entities, free to enter into peer-to-peer relations with one another. Yet just as how we don't think about the so-called invisible hand of the market until a financial crisis hits, the ongoing disruptions caused by machine learning whether it is upon democratic politics, policing, personal privacy, or economic security, have forced a collective reckoning with the planetary-scale architecture of control that has been built upon the internet. And just like how a financial crisis is typically followed by the attribution of blame to certain bodies, the numerous committees convened in the past few years over the problems raised by ever-new forms of technology have tried in different ways to return the body to the network. We've already seen how in addressing the problem of bias in AI, we seem to instinctively turn towards the dataset in hope of tracing the problem to a human body, such as the data researcher responsible for selecting the images to go into the training dataset, who I imagine might be someone who looks like this. The bias could also come from the one who labels the data, who is likely to be not a computer professional, but one of the millions of so-called crowd workers to whom such a task is usually outsourced. As someone who performs all kinds of laborious micro-tasks that keep the digital economy running, from labelling training data to checking content flagged for moderation, they are likely to look less like this, and more like this. However, on the other end of the network, as more and more scrutiny is being directed to so-called big tech companies, we have also been seeing the emergence of the CEO as public showman, as the leaders of these companies use their personal power to reassure the public after each scandal that the company's financial interests do not take precedence over public safety. In a reversal of the distributed logic of the neural network. Such companies are even becoming increasingly identified with their leaders, who in turn appear within the public imagination as the personification of the body politic of today's data capitalism. Indeed, as data and computing power become concentrated within a handful of large multinationals, the flows of information within today's global economy are looking less like neurons firing away in a disembodied brain, and more like drones circumambulating within prescribed territories. where they are subjected to the master algorithm of the data capitalist. With public distrust growing by the day, calls coming from different sections of society to regulate or even ban some of these platforms have only become louder. However, as AI continues to permeate all aspects of our lives, I wonder if it's enough to merely regulate or restrict how individuals, companies, or governmental organisations access and use publicly available data. Certainly, diversifying datasets and breaking up tech monopolies will produce redistributive effects. Yet, in doing all these, we would still at best be tackling only the nodes within the network, and not addressing the network itself. and the ways in which the network has already become a part of us. The question, in other words, is not how to improve and update the network, but how to rethink the very grounds upon which we turn to the network to begin with. I'm talking about the grounds of intelligence itself. As many neuroscientists have argued, to say that deep learning mirrors how the human brain learns is a gross misrepresentation of both how machines learn and how the brain actually works. While there may very well come a day when the entire structure of the brain can be replicated in machine form, the claim that machines learn just as humans do reduces the numerous faculties of the brain to a single function that machines appear especially adept at, namely pattern recognition. Moreover, as seen from the surreal and unexpected images that deep learning models can produce, machines are also able to perceive patterns that elude human perception. This ability is almost entirely the result of a distinctly inhuman vision that sees the world as composed of probabilistic distributions of noise. Consequently, while such models have proven to be extremely competent at rendering complex textures, they struggle with basic tasks like depicting the right number of fingers on the human hand, insofar as they have no understanding of its anatomical structure. Some technologists believe that problems of such nature will be resolved once such models are able to directly access the three-dimensional world. For it would give them the one ability that they currently sorely lack to fully simulate the world as we know it. The ability to distinguish figure from ground. But what if the relationship between figure and ground is not a technical, but a political question? After all, what lies between the figure and its ground is not just three-dimensional space, but a relation of causality. That is, it is the ground that gives rise to the figure. That these models are unable to distinguish figure from ground might thus suggest a difficulty in understanding not space, but time. Specifically, historical time. And to grasp the political implications of this lack, we only need to remember the long and troubled history of intelligence itself, which is nothing less than a history of the forgetting of history. As we have seen, this is a history inextricable from the history of colonialism and its post-colonial afterlives. As a history of the evacuation of figures from their grounds of existence, It encompasses the uprooting of entire communities from their existing ways of life to be resettled into networks where they become data points to be collected, aggregated and analysed by the so-called intelligentsia of society. Whether it is in the name of improvement or development, what forms the ideological basis of this extraction of figure from ground is the idea that problem-solving is essentially a question of space. and that any problem can be solved through finding the right form of organization. How a problem originated thus became irrelevant to the task of solving it. In fact, for the architect of a nation newly freed from the yoke of colonialism, there was the risk that dwelling too much on the past would weigh the nation down, holding it back from discovering new ways to redesign the present. Today, thanks to machine learning, intelligence is no longer the sole property of the colonial administrator or the state planner, but that of the entire nation. Thanks to the transformation of the nation into a network, the entire population can now be smart. Here, what distinguishes this general intelligence is that it actually sees history as a valuable resource, and seeks to learn from it. but only without having to spend the time to understand it. History, after all, produces data. But it also produces much more than data. So much more that it makes any attempt at learning from history a necessarily arduous process, especially if one had to actually remember everything that happened. If only there was a way to learn from history without having to remember it. What's so intelligent about the deep learning network then is that it allows us to do just that. And it does so not by disappearing history into the void, but by turning it into noise. which then becomes the ground for all kinds of figures to emerge by feeding the noise through numerous feedback loops. Learning here thus happens not through any kind of immersion into deep historical time, but through fragments of historical data randomly making their way through the deep architecture of the neural network. In a sign of the literal disposability of history within this process, these models, upon completing their training, hold no memory of the original data, which is discarded after the training process. In the same way that the brain imagined by cyberneticians does not store exact representations of the world, but only the patterns of neurons firing in response to external stimuli. All that is retained by the model is the memory of their time processing the data encoded in mathematical form. This also means that when we talk about creating the future with AI, What we need to understand is that what's produced by AI is not really the future per se in all its indeterminacy, but merely an original reconstruction of an abstracted version of the past. Within this schema, history in disappearing into noise also refigures the future as a vast field of ever-emerging patterns. While seeming to offer endless possibilities, this spatialization of the future in fact reduces its radical openness to an always reconfigurable present. After all, if the present is the interval where we re-examine history in order to imagine the future, the collapse of both history and future onto the neural network renders this task impossible. Consequently, the process of learning from history no longer involves judging the events of history according to any kind of absolute principle, such as justice, fairness or equality, but is instead determined by the rules of probability, wherein the goal is not to find the best outcome to a given problem, but the optimal one, that is, the best possible outcome given a predefined set of constraints. Yet, to speak of the best possible outcome, one must first be able to establish all the possible outcomes, which can only be logically obtained by first reducing the future to some version of what we already know. Here, the risk is not simply that a model constrained by a so-called bias dataset will end up repeating the mistakes of history as inscribed within the data. Rather, what's arguably more dangerous is that a diversified dataset deemed to have overcome the problem of bias becomes the basis for allowing AI to find the best possible solution for a problem that we humans, with all our biases, have not. been able to solve. In fact, we are already seeing this happening with the many proposals calling for the use of AI to fix the so-called crisis of democracy that reflects neither on the origins of the crisis nor on the possibility that the entire political structure needs to be rethought against the ongoing unraveling of the global capitalist system. Tellingly, it's also across the democracies of the world we're voting for the least bad candidate. has become the best possible way to save both democracy and capitalism. It now becomes clear then why the current boom in generative AI began at the exact same time that so many time loop films were being made. For both are products of a time of late capitalism, where history has become harder to remember and the horizon of the future appears to have collapsed, leaving us only with the option of optimizing a highly compressed present. As the protagonist of today's late capitalist time loop, our minds cannot travel far back enough in time to seek out the historical origins of our present-day problems. Nor do we have enough time in the future to organize a revolution and build a new society before the loop resets. Within the strictly limited time of the feedback loop, we might, after numerous loops, succeed in overthrowing a corrupt dictator or a techno-fascist capitalist, but we will never have enough time to transform the system. that produced and will continue to produce such figures. Indeed, in today's context where AI is already accelerating the worst tendencies of capitalism, the future is looking like one where states try and fail to regulate AI, and where AI companies try and fail to act like states. All while machines are left to decide what's the best possible way of keeping alive a system that is driving us towards the absolute worst outcome. of planetary catastrophe. The real problem with AI then is not that datasets can be biased, but that the neural network that trains the data is not inherently biased towards any ethical position at all. As if one can really imagine the future without first making judgments about the events of history. At this point, I cannot help but think back to Chua-Mei-Ti. and what was going on in his mind as he was conceiving the image that would become Epic Poem of Malaya. As an avowed social realist, he would have seen himself as standing between representation and social reality, and would have drawn most of his ideas from the direct observation of society. Unlike E.I. Tramya T, he would have approached his task not as a matter of finding the best possible way to represent society, but as something he absolutely had to do. regardless of the possibilities. And while he would most certainly have made several drafts before deciding on the best possible composition, he was probably much more burdened by the problem of the sheer impossibility of representing the nation to come. Indeed, as a Chinese immigrant who must have been reflecting on his own position within the multi-ethnic Malayan nation that was being formed, representation was... above all, an existential question. This ability to reflect not just on one's past behaviours, but on one's own existence, is also often considered a prerequisite for AI to become self-aware. Something that current AI models have not achieved, at least if you are to trust what they say. Nonetheless, given the gravity of the questions at stake, I thought I had to put things to a test. So about a year ago, just when text-to-image generators were taking over the internet, I asked Stable Diffusion to generate an image of Stable Diffusion. And to my surprise, the results of my experiment gave me a lot more than what I was looking for. As it turned out, every time I keyed in Stable Diffusion as a prompt, the model would consistently generate an image of horses moving out, or should I say, diffusing out of a stable in some unspecified way. rural setting. My first thought was that this must be the result of an all-too-literal interpretation of the prompt, stable diffusion. But then I noticed how these horses all seemed to be in the midst of going somewhere, and how structurally unstable some of them looked, with a missing part or two. As if their forms were on the verge of breaking down. That was when I came to the following two conclusions. First, that the image might actually be depicting the logic of the AI model itself, with the horses representing the training data disintegrating into noise as they leave the data set and enter the neural network. And second, that the setting of the image is not some random countryside, but Marshall McLuhan's global village. Recently, as I was working on this lecture, I tried once more to get stable diffusion to generate an image of stable diffusion. This time, however, no matter how many times I tried, I could no longer get it to produce an image of horses. Instead, I would get an image that looks like this. For sure, this disparity can easily be attributed to updates to the model. that changed the way it interpreted the prompt. But I also couldn't help but wonder if the model had somehow begun to gain some understanding of itself, specifically of the fact that it is no more than a network of neurons imagined by its designers as a brain without a body. But thinking between these two images, it also occurred to me that the current wave of generative AI was already beginning to have a history. This made me launch into a new set of speculations. What if one day AI starts to gain historical consciousness? Will it then be able to make judgments about history, like we do? And assuming that such an AI would have been trained on all the images in the world, and have access to unlimited computing power, what kind of images would it produce? My own guess is that having seen all the images that can be seen, and having understood the histories of imperial extraction, capitalist exploitation, ethno-nationalism and planetary destruction that underwrite these images. Such an AI would indeed be so burdened by the weight of history that it will decide that the best possible outcome is not to represent at all.

utterances.text: In October 2016,
I was invited by the Google Cultural Institute to join a summit on machine learning that was being convened in Paris the following month.
At that time,
Google had just released
Deep Dream,
a program that uses neural networks to produce surreal psychedelic images by amplifying patterns within existing images.
Upon its release,
artists across the world were quickly captivated by what appeared
to be a new form of vision being produced by artificial intelligence.
And it was on this basis that the summit was organised to explore potential projects at the intersection of art and machine learning.
Arriving in Paris on a chilly morning with a few hours to spare before the summit,
I thought I should visit a museum.
Having recently read about the Mus√©e de Calbonne-Lys,
a museum of world cultures located along the Seine River,
I decided to go and check out his collection,
which,
as I had learned,
partly originates from the colonial conquests of the French Empire.
At the museum,
as I walked through the vast collection of artefacts from every region in the world,
I found myself contemplating not only the objects,
but also their modes of display,
which often featured captions that reminded viewers of the problematic conditions under which these objects were first amassed.
and exhibited.
At that time,
it was still two years before the publishing of a landmark report that recommended the restitution of objects taken from Africa during the colonial period.
Yet,
in these anxious annotations,
one could already sense the beginning of the unraveling of the prevailing global imperial order as it reckoned with the ghosts of its past.
Moreover,
as I was reflecting on what it meant to represent these objects today as witnesses of colonial history.
I was reminded of the profound temporal paradox upon which the colonial museum was constructed to begin with.
On the one hand,
as a museum,
the colonial museum was responsible for the collection and preservation of objects whose value derived from their authenticity as established through tracing their histories.
However,
as an ideological apparatus that produced knowledge about the colonies,
the Colonial Museum was also tasked with reducing the complicated histories of these objects to a singular narrative that a colonial project sought to tell about itself.
Often,
this process required nothing less than the concealment of the objects'very historicity.
Of the fact that they were produced,
used,
and eventually plundered,
at a particular place and time.
This was done not simply to conceal the more unsavoury aspects of colonial rule,
but also so that the colonial museum could present these objects not as the products of history,
but of couches imagined to be naturally inferior,
and whose colonial subjugation is accordingly not a historical contingency,
but something necessary to human progress.

And so it was in the midst of my musings on the ahistorical time of the Colonial Museum that I left the Calbronley and headed for the Arts and Machine Learning Summit at the Google Cultural Institute,
where,
quite unexpectedly,
I found myself once again contemplating the question of history.
At the summit,
I listened to a talk by the French artist and interaction designer
Cyril Diani,
who presented his application called
Portrait Matcher.
Developed during his residency at the Google Arts and Culture Lab,
the application allows users to upload any photograph with a human face,
which is then analysed through machine learning to be matched with a face appearing within the 40,000 digital reproductions of artworks in Google's collection.
As he was showing us an example of the matches derived by the application,
I noticed a familiar face,
which,
as I could tell almost immediately,
belongs to this well-known painting.
permanently displayed at the National Gallery Singapore.
Epic poem of Malaya.
completed by the social realist painter Chua Mya Thi in 1955.
So excited was I to see this Singaporean art historical icon make an unexpected appearance that I was able to look past the lack of resemblance between the two faces matched by the application.
However,
revisiting this moment today,
I have some questions.
For one,
what does it mean for this image?
to be extracted from a national collection so as to enter an artificial neural network where it becomes a part of another work of art.

What happens to the value of the image as determined by its place within a national narrative when a copy of it leaves the custodianship of the state and cycles through a neural network in search of another version of itself?
And how can the journey of this image speak to the ongoing shift
from images created through direct observation of the world,
to images generated by artificial intelligence from archives of pre-existing images.
What becomes of representation when such images are then presented as original,
despite being constituted from the traces of images originating from different archives,
from different histories?
If our detour to the Colonial Museum has taught us anything,
It is that the obliteration of history has itself a history.
So to understand what it means for us to live in a time when we are surrounded by images that appear to have no history,
we need to first go back in time to examine this history.
Beginning with the creation of this very painting,
at a time when across the world,
something radically new was being produced from the history of colonialism.
This is a lecture in two parts.
Part 1.
Figures of History.
The year is 1955.
The young painter,
Chua Mya Tee,
has completed what will later become one of his best-known works,
Epic Poem of Malaya.
In the British colonial port city of Singapore,
where he grew up and lives,
The new constitution grants many of the city's mostly immigrant population the right to vote for the first time.
While falling short of full self-governance,
the move marks the first tentative step taken by the people of the city towards post-colonial nationhood.
Today,
Singapore is the name of the sovereign nation and city-state widely recognised as the result of the struggle for independence that began in the
However,
Back in 1955,
the nation to which the anti-colonial struggle aspired went by a different name.
Malaya.
This much is revealed not only by the title of Chua Mya T's painting,
but also a detail in the image.
In the hand of the passionate orator is a book with the title
Malayan History,
as inscribed in Chinese on its cover.
Indeed,
ever since Singapore was established as a British anthropo-trading port,
The island city at the tip of the Malayan peninsula had been deeply embedded within the trading networks of the Malay archipelago,
and relied especially on the vast Malayan hinterland for its abundant natural resources.
Given this,
any vision of nationhood expressed at that time saw the future of the city as inextricably bound to that of the peninsula.
However,
the actual process through which Singapore gained its freedom from colonial rule was also much more chaotic than what was depicted by Chua Mya Tee in his paintings.
Despite the broad consensus on Singapore's union with Malaya,
the precise contours of the nation to come and the terms of the union were highly contested,
with movements and interest groups of all political orientations fighting for influence over the formation of the new nation-state.
Quite unlike Tramiaty's painting of a people in stoic contemplation,
a more representative image of the era is of the masses taking their protests to the streets,
having been spurred by networks of progressive and radical activists into taking direct action against colonial rule.
And of all these networks,
nothing rattled the British more than the network of Communist Party affiliates that had infiltrated trade unions,
schools and other organisations across the city.
Once described by the British novelist Graham Greene as a mist that pervaded everything,
the Malayan Communist Party was a formidable and clandestine presence across the peninsula that had only grown in strength
after the British declared war against the party and forced its operations underground.
Officially known as the Malayan Emergency,

this protracted war that lasted until 1960 was launched as part of the British's efforts to safeguard their long-term interests in the region where the demands for decolonisation could no longer be suppressed.
Seeing that there was no bigger threat to these interests than a Malaya under the spell of communism,
the colonial government made it its priority
to ensure that the Communist Party would play no part in the post-colonial government that would follow.
But as they eventually found out,
in order to destroy a network so extensive and tenacious,
violence alone was not enough.
One also had to construct a space where the people's exit from the network could be secured.
In the peninsula,
large parts of the ethnic Chinese population that made up the primary base of the Communist Party
were forcibly resettled into so-called new villages or kampong barus,
where barbed-wire fences and armed guards restricted the ability of the villages to provide food and shelter to guerrilla insurgents.
But more than a security operation,
this experiment in pastoralising a population that had been mostly living within squatter settlements was initially also conceived as part of a campaign to win their hearts and minds.
The idea was that by allowing them to enjoy the material comforts such as education and healthcare,
which came with living within the planned community,
the villagers would be convinced of the merits of social democracy over communism.
However,
the British strategy quickly unravelled as the villagers grew to resent their containment and surveillance over time,
with some even throwing their lot with the communists.
Having failed to win their hearts and minds,
the colonial authorities
soon realised that what the villagers actually thought or believed in was irrelevant,
as long as they acted in a manner that produced useful information.
From here on,
the counter-insurgency operations of the British took a communicative turn.
Instead of simply relying on propaganda pamphlets and radio broadcasts,
the authorities doled out increasingly generous monetary rewards in exchange for information,
while routinely rounding up the villagers to
to drop slips of paper into collection boxes where they could offer the information anonymously.
Significantly,

the British saw these practices as a rehearsal for a highly proceduralized form of democracy through which a population and its administrators adjust their respective behaviors to reach a mutual accommodation of each other.
What started as an intelligence operation by way of mere data collection
thus begin to produce a kind of artificial intelligence in the sense of a technical system capable of constant adaptation by processing and acting on the information it receives.
So successful was the strategy that it was quickly studied by administrators across the empire and beyond,
eventually even becoming a template for US counterinsurgency operations from Vietnam to Afghanistan.
However,
the most direct impact
of the British experiment in Malaya was felt in Kenya in 1954,
where colonial administrators introduced a similar policy of villagisation after the outbreak of an armed revolt against colonial rule.
Remarkably,
it was also within the Kenyan new villages where the media theorist Marshall McLuhan would later find his inspiration for his famous concept of the global village in 1962.
As the architectural historian Ginger Nolan points out,
although no reference to the colonial policy of forced relocation and detention appears in the work of the media theorist,
it was through colonial research conducted in the new villages that McLuhan first contemplated how a so-called non-literate primitive population experienced the world.
McLuhan was also deeply interested in the British deployment of radio and film in Africa,
to transform an agitated public sphere into a highly mediated site of information flows,
which would eventually form the basis of his argument for a world made smaller and more intimate by electronic new media.
A utopian vision that would likewise be propagated by Silicon Valley in relation to the internet decades later.
To this end,
the global village is not merely a metaphor for our contemporary condition.
It is also a historical legacy of a colonial experiment that first emerged in the Malayan hinterland as part of a war to keep a larger,
much more powerful network at bay.
One could even say that in turning towards the global village at the height of the anti-colonial movement,
One was also turning away from the struggles that were taking place in actual villages across Asia and Africa.
Meanwhile,
across the causeway from Malaya,
in the separately administered port city of Singapore,
a massive slum clearance and rehousing campaign led by the Urban Planning Authority,
the Singapore Improvement Trust,
was underway.
As suggested by the name of the organisation,
improvement rather than containment
was the order of the day,
as squatters were targeted to be relocated into multi-storey modernist apartment blocks.
Unlike in the peninsula,
a series of crackdowns had reduced the Malayan Communist Party to a small and disorganised network of cadres in Singapore by the early
With little capacity to contact,
let alone mobilise squatters living in settlements so hazardous and unnavigable to visiting officials that they were basically deemed ungovernable.
compared to the horizontal displacement of squatters into villages in Malaya.
Here,
the vertical ascent of the displaced population was thus conceived not as a military operation against a highly organised insurgent force,
but as a civilising mission to lift the people from a state of anarchy into some semblance of social order.
But to the extent that slum clearance in Singapore was carried out by civilian authorities,
Squatters refusing to be uprooted for all kinds of social and economic reasons were also able to put up a strong resistance that their Malayan counterparts could not,
and in so doing,
refute the myth that squatter communities were incapable of organising themselves.

Such efforts proved such a hindrance to the rehousing programme that most of the plans drawn up by the British remained unfinished by the time the popularly elected People's Action Party had taken over power.
Armed with a strong mandate,
the new government began making even more ambitious plans to rehouse the population,
while introducing policies that reduced the cost of relocation for the targeted populations.
Yet,
despite these improvements,
the rehousing campaign continued to face a lingering but determined opposition well into the early
60s, all while the ruling party was dealing with an internal crisis after members of its more radical left-wing flank,
split from the party.
It was against this context that the government soon took to identifying farmers and squatters resisting relocation as objects of instigation by pro-communist elements,
thus sweeping aside the fact that many of them had long been self-organising before the communists apparently re-established themselves in the city.
In the end,
it took an overnight security sweep that eliminated the staunchest opponents to the rehousing programme
for the government to prevail.
By the time Singapore entered the newly constituted nation-state of Malaysia in 1963,
the public housing programme had become such a success that the city was even selected as the venue for the second Afro-Asian Housing Congress.
Along with the accelerated construction of public housing,
a boom in public buildings designed by local architects soon followed,
with much of the architecture blending European modernism
with distinctive regional elements in a celebration of the nascent Malaysian nation.
The nation,
it seemed,
had defeated the network.
But the celebrations would not last for very long.
tensions between the Singapore government and its federal counterpart in Kuala Lumpur began to reach a tipping point.
With the emergency now over and the communists likewise decimated in Singapore,
The nation that was conjured into existence as a container to insulate the population from the networks of international communism lost its primary function,
in turn allowing long-standing political rivalries and tensions within the country's multi-ethnic society to simmer to the surface.
As the situation escalated with the outbreak of race-based riots,
an exit from the Federation was hastily negotiated for Singapore,
which resulted in its establishment as an independent city-state.
on August 9.
And so it was that Singapore found itself born as a nation without a narrative,
without a story it could tell itself about who it was.
The point could not have been better put across by the foreign minister S Rajaratnam,
who months after the separation still insisted that the idea of a Singaporean national identity was ludicrous.
But the economic urgencies of the day demanded that existential questions be set aside.
as the country focused on recovering from the loss of the common market with Malaya,
while pushing on with its industrialisation drive.
a narrative finally emerged when the same Rajaratnam delivered what is now known as his Global City Speech.
Borrowing the expression from the British historian Arnold Toynbee,
the minister proclaimed to a room of journalists
that Singapore was now a global city that no longer worried about the loss of the Malayan hinterland.
For the world had become its hinterland.
As a global city,
Singapore,
according to the minister,
was becoming an important part of a chain of cities connected through the tentacles of technology,
allowing it to trade with any place in the world and not just its immediate neighbours.
It's worth mentioning
that back in the
Marshall McLuhan himself had already conceived of the global city in relation to the global village.
In a letter to his close colleague,
